H0.text: Air density and pressure are lower when gas molecules are warm.

H1.text: They are unchanged when gas molecules are warm, meaning that air density and pressure do not change.

H2.text: They are equal when gas molecules are warm.

H3.text: They are greater when gas molecules are warm, indicating that air density and pressure increase.

A4.text: For real gases, the molecules do interact via attraction or repulsion depending on temperature and pressure, and heating or cooling does occur.

A5.text: Since the ideal gas law neglects both molecular size and intermolecular attractions, it is most accurate for monatomic gases at high temperatures and low pressures.
